Rationale  The ongoing Nepal Education for All (EFA) program (2004–2009) 
is a high-priority national program for basic education (grades 1–
5)  supported  by  a  number  of  development  partners,  including 
ADB. EFA aims to (i) increase equity of access to education and 
social  inclusion;  (ii)  improve  quality  and  relevance;  and  (iii) 
enhance efficiency and institutional capacity. 
 
As the country is emerging from years of conflict following the 
changes in the political context since April 2006, Nepal is poised 
to  enter  a  new  era  of  development  that  has  raised  people’s 
expectations and demands with respect to the delivery of good 
quality  education.  The  education  system  is  under  pressure  to 
further improve its services beyond what has been achieved so far 
under  EFA.  Within  this  changing  context,  the  Government  of 
Nepal recognizes that 5 years of basic education is not sufficient 
and intends to extend basic education coverage to grades 1–8 
and secondary education to grades 9–12. The Government also 
intends  to  improve  synergies  between  basic  education  and 
secondary  education  to  achieve  a  more  holistic  approach  to 
school education.  
 
The Government has prepared a draft school sector reform (SSR) 
core document which will guide the preparation and the transition 
from the current subsector approach, with education financed by 
programs such as EFA, to an integrated school sector.

ii 
 
  The draft core document provides an overview of policy intents 
and strategic options for an integrated school system. It provides 
the rationale for extending basic education to grades 1–8, and 
secondary  education  to  grades  9–12.  It  also  takes  a  holistic 
approach  to  school  education  by  integrating  early  childhood 
development,  formal  education,  alternative  education,  and 
technical  education.  The  core  document  details  the  technical, 
managerial, regulatory, and financial issues, and the challenges 
involved in developing an integrated education system. The draft 
core  document  contains  a  well-articulated  and  clear  vision  for 
SSR. It provides a solid basis for further elaboration of the reform 
process. 
 
The core document acknowledges the achievements of EFA and 
the national movement that it has created. SSR is viewed as a 
combination of affirmative actions and policy changes aimed at 
attaining the EFA goals by 2015. At the same time, SSR builds 
upon lessons learned from EFA and attempts to address systemic 
issues that impede the progress of the education system. 
 
The preparation of a comprehensive reform program such as SSR 
is a complex and lengthy process that requires several important 
steps. The Government has prepared an initial SSR transitional 
plan that sets immediate (2007), medium-term (2010), and long-
term (2015–2016) outcomes and outputs for the key policy reform 
areas  for  SSR.  Planned  actions  under  the  transitional  plan 
between  2007  and  2010  include  the  preparation  of  regulatory 
frameworks,  policy  guidelines,  norms  and  standards,  and 
operational procedures. It also includes a model-building of the 
extension of basic education from grades 1–5 to grades 1–8 in 
selected  districts.  Furthermore,  stakeholders’  capacity-
development requirements at all levels are to be identified, and 
capacity development initiated. 
 
It is expected that lessons learned and experiences gained from 
implementation of grade 1–8 basic education in selected districts 
and  schools  will  result  in  an  improved  and  final  SSR  core 
document. The final core document will guide the implementation 
of an SSR program expected to start in FY2010. It will serve as a 
policy and planning guide for gradual introduction of the grade 1–
12 integrated system throughout the country.

iii 
 
Program Cluster  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  launched  the  Education 
Sector Program (ESP) cluster and approved its first subprogram 
for an amount of $30 million on 1 December 2006. The ESP 
supports  the  Government’s  school  sector  reform  (SSR),  which 
aims to restructure the school system into an integrated grade 1–
12 system in a phased manner. The expected outcome of the 
ESP  is  a  more  equitable,  inclusive,  effective,  and  holistic 
education system.  
 
The ESP adopted an innovative program cluster design to allow a 
phased  approach  to  prepare  and  implement  SSR.  Three 
subprograms will be developed and implemented in accordance 
with the time frame and progress of the SSR from 2007 to 2012. 
 
The ESP subprogram I supports the ongoing Nepal EFA program 
(2004–2009)  for  basic  and  primary  education  (grades  1–5).  A 
capacity-development grant of $2 million complements the ESP 
subprogram I to develop Government stakeholders’ capacity in 
policy analysis, formulation, and coordination. It also supports the 
preparation of an SSR core document.  
 
The ESP subprogram II will support the preparation and transition 
to  SSR,  in  particular  a  model-building  exercise  of  the  basic 
education extension to grades 1–8 in a few districts, as well as 
broad capacity development for system readiness. The draft SSR 
core document will be further developed and is expected to be 
accepted by the Government, development partners and other 
stakeholders. It is expected that lessons learned from the ESP 
subprogram II will help the Government implement a countrywide 
grade 1–8 restructuring.  
 
The ESP subprogram III will support full implementation of the 
SSR once the core document is finalized, financed, and the legal, 
governance, and financing framework is adjusted to a grade 1–12 
school system. 
 
   
Impact and Outcome  The expected overall impact of the ESP cluster program, including 
the ESP subprogram II, is enhanced educational attainment and 
livelihood  for  all  children,  particularly  girls  and  disadvantaged 
groups. The expected outcome of ESP subprogram II is a broadly 
accepted  and  adequately  financed  SSR  policy,  program,  and 
financing framework.

iv 
 
Financing Plan  The Government has requested a program grant of $8 million from 
ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  to  contribute  to  the  SSR 
transitional  plan.  In  parallel  with the ADB grant, as part  of the 
European  Commission  contribution  to  the  school  sector,  the 
European Commission will provide a program grant of €6 million to 
support organizational capacity-development activities, both within 
key sector institutions in the country and with major stakeholders 
and communities. All EFA development partners have agreed to 
jointly finance the Program within the existing EFA joint financing 
arrangement (JFA).  
 
   
Program Period and  The ESP subprogram II will be implemented over 4 years from 
Tranching  January 2008 to December 2011. It is expected that program 
completion will be in December 2011 and the grant closing date 
will be June 2012. The grant will be released in a single tranche 
upon  grant  effectiveness.  All  tranche  release  conditions  have 
been met. 
 
   
Executing Agency and  The Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES) is the Executing 
Implementation  Agency  and  the  Department  of  Education  (DOE)  is  the 
Arrangements  Implementing Agency. A central-level coordination committee has 
been established at MOES to effectively coordinate and monitor 
SSR  capacity-development  activities  implemented  by  various 
MOES  line  agencies.  The  EFA’s  JFA  will  be  amended  to 
incorporate SSR transitional activities under ESP subprogram II. 
Reporting  and  monitoring  of  progress  on  SSR  transitional 
activities will be fully integrated into the ongoing reporting and 
monitoring activities under EFA.

v 
 
Counterpart Funds  The  local  currency  funds  generated  from  the  proceeds  of  the 
program grant will be used by the Government to contribute to the 
cost associated with implementation of the SSR transitional plan. 
   
Program Benefits and  ESP II will benefit the children and youth of Nepal, particularly 
Beneficiaries  those who would otherwise be denied a quality and affordable 
education. Through the model building of the 1–8 basic education 
in  selected  districts  and  through  system-wide  capacity 
development  of  the  education  key  stakeholders,  the  education 
system will be in a better position to successfully implement the 
SSR reform on a countrywide basis in FY2010. This will ultimately 
result in an education system that is capable of providing better 
quality education, resulting in enhanced educational attainment 
and livelihoods for all children, particularly girls and disadvantaged 
groups. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Potential delay in the political transition may delay some aspects 
of  the  reform  process.  Strategies  related  to  some  areas  of 
education governance, financing, and structure may be decided at 
a  later  stage.  However,  the  model-building  exercise,  capacity-
development activities and further preparation in key education 
reform areas of quality improvement and assurance, and social 
inclusion, do not require the political process to be finalized, and 
hence will not be affected. Anticorruption measures under ESP 
subprogram  II  will  follow  the  provisions  under  the  EFA’s  JFA. 
Particularly,  EFA  partners  endorsed  a  financial  management 
improvement action plan prepared by DOE. The EFA midterm 
review concluded that the budgeting, accounting, and reporting 
procedures under the JFA comply with fiduciary requirements in 
an  acceptable  manner.  Measures  to  (i)  improve  financial 
management  pertinent  to  timely  disbursement  to  districts  and 
schools  and  submission  of  the  financial  monitoring  report,  (ii) 
simplify and clarify guidelines, and (iii) strengthen monitoring and 
coordination mechanisms at all levels, are being undertaken by 
DOE. DOE’s financial management improvement action plan also 
comprises  capacity  development  in  social  auditing  and  school 
auditing.  Both  ESP  subprograms  I  and  II  have  provisions  to 
support such capacity development.

II.  BACKGROUND 
A.  The Program Cluster and Timing of Subprograms 
 
2.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  launched  the  ESP  and  approved  its  first

3.  The ESP adopted an innovative program cluster design to allow a phased approach to

B.  Program-Based Approach   
 
5.  The second innovative feature of the ESP is the use of a program-based approach. EFA 
is Nepal’s first truly program-based approach in education under which development partners 
pool funds and use country systems and fully harmonized procedures for their contributions. 
Core financing of EFA is through a joint financing arrangement (JFA) under which development 
partners3 provide budgetary support to EFA. Program activities and budget items are mutually 
agreed upon by EFA partners before the beginning of each fiscal year, through a review of an 
annual rolling plan, the annual strategic implementation plan (ASIP), and the annual work plan 
and budget (AWPB). Development partners' annual commitments are based on outcome and 
process performance indicators.  
 
6.  The  ESP  is  one  of  the  most  far-reaching  programs  in  terms  of  alignment  with 
government procedures and donor harmonization in education, and the first program-based 
approach supported by ADB. The ESP uses program lending and adjusts it to program-based 
approach  features.  As  such,  ESP  tranche  releases  are  contingent  upon  annually  agreed 
program outcomes and progress rather than policy milestones. The ESP also marked a radical 
change in ADB assistance in education in Nepal from a project approach to a multipartner 
program-based approach.

III.  THE MACROECONOMIC AND POLITICAL CONTEXT  
8.  Despite political uncertainty, Nepal has achieved broad macroeconomic stability over the 
past 5 years. Annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth during 2003–2007 averaged 2.7% 
and inflation was 5.5%. Economic growth is expected to increase in anticipation of further 
stabilization of the political process, which holds promise of sustained peace and a transition to 
a more productive economy. Per capita GDP reached $312 in 2006, compared to $241 in 2001. 
In addition to a consolidation of the peace process, the country will also require increased 
resource mobilization and productivity gains in order to achieve higher sustainable growth. An 
investor-friendly climate would create more employment, generate technological benefits, and 
contribute to overall economic competitiveness, while a skilled labor force would contribute to 
raising domestic productivity.  
 
9.  The nonagricultural sector is gradually diversifying and creating higher-paying jobs. In 
addition,  an  increasing  number  of  people  are  seeking  employment  abroad.  Remittances—
amounting to $1.3 billion, or 15% of GDP, in 2006—are one of the country’s major income 
sources and have helped improve the living standards of a large number of people. Appropriate 
training opportunities for workers abroad are needed under the reform process in education.   
 
10.  The Government’s 3-year interim plan for FY2008–FY20104 puts special emphasis on 
increasing  public  expenditure  to  enhance  employment,  as  well  as  on  peace  building, 
reconstruction, rehabilitation, reintegration, inclusion, and revitalization of the economy. The 
annual average economic growth rate for the interim plan period is projected to be 5.5%. 
 
11.  Within this context, the Government recognizes the importance of the education sector. 
Education is the largest sector within the government budget. For FY2008, NRs28.07 billion out 
of a total budget of NRs168.99 billion is allocated to the education sector. This represents 
16.6% of the total budget, up from just under 16.0% in FY2007.  
 
12.  On the political front, the country underwent a political transformation following the April 
2006 ceasefire. As a result of a popular movement, the parliament was restored. Subsequently, 
in November 2006 a comprehensive peace accord was signed between a seven-party alliance 
and  the  Communist  Party  of  Nepal  (Maoist).  An  interim  constitution  was  agreed  on  18 
December 2006, promulgated on the first day of the formation of the interim parliament (15 
January 2007) and amended twice—in March and June 2007. The interim constitution has the 
following provisions pertinent to education: (i) each community will have the right to receive 
basic education in its mother language, and (ii) each citizen will have the right to receive free 
education up to the secondary level as provided by law. 
 
13.  In mid-September 2007, the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist) withdrew from the 
interim government, and constituent assembly elections originally scheduled for 22 November 
2007 were postponed until mid-April 2008. However, the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)

14.  The constituent assembly will be tasked with writing a new constitution in line with the 
vision of a decentralized political structure for Nepal. Political consensus about a move to

education as a national responsibility. The educational governance system will need to be 
aligned with changes in the overall government structure. 
 
15.  The political changes in the country have improved the chances for lasting peace and 
the creation of a prosperous, peaceful, and inclusive Nepal. The changes have also raised 
people’s expectations and demands with respect to public services. Demand from the people for 
an equitable delivery of good quality education is increasing. The educational management 
systems  at  various  levels,  including  the  schools,  are  under  pressure  to  respond  to  these 
emerging challenges by improving their services. The restoration of peace has created an 
atmosphere more conducive to educational reconstruction and development. 
 
IV.  PROGRESS OF IMPLEMENTATION OF SUBPROGRAM I 
A.  Program Implementation 
 
1.  Education For All Outcome Progress  
16.  EFA  is  currently  in  its  third  year  of  implementation.  An  EFA  midterm  review  was 
conducted in May 2007, with national stakeholders and all EFA development partners. Overall, 
the  midterm  review  concluded  that  access  to  schools  has  improved  considerably,  but 
challenges remain in improving the quality and social and geographic equity of basic and 
primary  education.  Findings  of  the  midterm  review  on  outcomes  of  the  EFA  program  are 
summarized below. Appendix 2 contains a table with the status of EFA indicators.  
(i)  Early childhood development (ECD) centers have expanded, as is evident in the 
proportion of grade 1 students with ECD experience, which has increased from 
8% in 2001 to 18.3% in 2006. The percentage of dalit5 children enrolled in grade 
1 with ECD experience is 17.3%; for janajati6 children the figure is 21.0%. For 
other social groups the proportion of grade 1 students with ECD experience is 
16.5%.  
(ii)  Enrolment,  including  enrolment  of  girls,  has  increased.  This  has  led  to  an 
increase in the net enrolment rate, from 81% in 2001 to 87.4% in 2006. The 
percentage of dalit enrolments is 17.7%, janajati enrolments are 38%, while other 
social groups account for the remaining 44.3%. The gender parity index has also 
increased, from 0.6 in 2001 to 0.94 in 2006. The primary-level enrolment for girls 
is 48% of the total enrolment. The percentage of girls’ enrolment in mountain 
districts is 47.5%, in hill districts 49.7%, and in Terai districts 47.2%.

(iii)  The  rapid  increase  in  enrolment  has  also  resulted  in  an  increased  gross 
enrolment rate, from 123% in 2001 to 138.8% in 2006, which puts the schools 
under enormous pressure. The situation is of great concern, especially in grade 1 
where the gross intake rate is 148%.  
(iv)  The total survival rate to grade 5 is 80.3%, up from 66% in 2001. It is 77.4% for 
girls and 83.0% for boys. The survival rate ranges from 61.5% in the central Terai 
districts to 95.2% in the Kathmandu Valley. 
(v)  The student–teacher ratio has increased from 39:1 in 2001 to 45.2:1 in 2006, 
despite the allocation of additional teachers. The highest student–teacher ratio is 
in the Terai (58.1:1) while the lowest is in the Kathmandu Valley (16.2:1). 
(vi)  The  percentage  of  trained  teachers  has  increased  rapidly,  from  15%  of  all 
teachers in 2001 to 59.9% in 2006. 
(vii)  There is no information on learning achievement. A grade 5 national assessment 
conducted in 2003 showed improvements in learning achievement, but this data 
has not yet been brought up to date. 
 
17.  The midterm review recognized the progress of EFA in increased participation, including 
that of girls, the number of trained teachers, and the grade 5 survival rate. It also acknowledged 
EFA's contribution to keeping the school system operating during the insurgency period. The 
school system has demonstrated the robustness of service, even as the country has emerged 
from years of conflict. This is also despite the changing political situation and confusion caused 
by  2  years  of  uncertainty  regarding  the  direction  of  fundamental  changes  in  the  political 
environment. EFA as a national movement has supported the system in meeting the immediate 
needs in education during this difficult period. 
  
18.  The midterm review findings also outlined the following challenges. 
(i)  Access to education has increased but in some areas this has been at the 
expense of quality of service delivery and efficiency. For instance, an increasing 
gross enrolment rate has caused crowding of schools and burdens on teachers, 
who could then not teach adequately. A relative decline in service delivery in turn 
resulted in an increased drop-out rate at grade 1.  
(ii)  As completion and transition rates increase, there is a risk of widening gaps 
between  the  socially  disadvantaged  groups  and  those  in  poor  and  remote 
districts, and the rest of the country.  
(iii)  The correlation between certain inputs and outcomes needs to be strengthened 
further. For instance, an increase in the number of ECD centers is not sufficiently 
reflected in an increase in grade 1 students with ECD experience, nor in a better 
survival rate of such students at grade 1.  
(iv)  Learning achievement is a core EFA performance indicator to measure quality. 
However, a reliable and standardized learning achievement test is yet to be 
developed in Nepal. 
 
19.  The above-mentioned issues provide some key lessons for a review of policy, strategy, 
and prioritization of resources in education under the future SSR: (i) how to meet public demand 
for education by increasing access to basic and primary education and at the same time 
improving quality of service delivery and internal efficiency; (ii) how to ensure social inclusion 
while maintaining a broader national target for education; and (iii) how to develop evidence-
based planning and management at all levels, based on a clear accountability mechanism that 
includes the development of sound performance indicators to measure quality and education 
outcomes.

2.  Education For All Implementation Strategies and Program Management  
20.  The  midterm  review  concluded  that  EFA’s  core  implementation  strategies  of

these strategies faced the following constraints.  
(i)  Governance structures could not perform as envisaged because of the unstable 
social and political situation. Decentralization has been hampered by disruption,

(ii)  Monitoring  and  supervision  at  district  and  school  levels  have  been  heavily

(iii)  Local stakeholders faced difficulties in planning, implementing, monitoring, and

and within districts.  
 
21.  The midterm review raised concern over the appropriate deployment and redeployment

V.  THE SCHOOL SECTOR REFORM 
 
A.  Status of the Draft School Sector Reform Core Document 
  
29.  The  Government  has  prepared  a  draft  SSR  core  document  which  will  guide  the 
preparation and the transition from the current subsector approach, with education financed by 
programs such as the EFA and the Secondary Education Support Project, to an integrated SSR. 
The final core document will guide the implementation of an SSR program expected to start in 
FY2010. It will serve as a policy and planning guide for gradual introduction of the grade 1–12 
integrated  system.  It  will  clarify  Government  commitments  with  respect  to  the  provision, 
promotion,  and  appraisal  of  educational  services  within  the  framework  of  the  grade  1–12 
system.  Major  strategies  relating  to  standards  of  services  and  performance—such  as 
management, financing, legal functions, and the regulatory framework—will be detailed. The

8 
 
final core document will describe operational procedures for delivering school education of an 
acceptable quality in partnership with the community and civil society. It will contain details of 
programs, the financing framework, and implementation. To write the core document, MOES 
mobilized  a  team  composed  of  thematic  groups  related  to  governance  and  management, 
quality, financing, social inclusion, structure, monitoring, and technical education and vocational 
training (TEVT).  
 
30.  The draft core document provides an overview of policy intents and strategic options for 
an integrated school system. It provides the rationale for extending basic education to grades 1–
8,  and  secondary  education  to  grades  9–12.  It  also  takes  a  holistic  approach  to  school 
education by integrating ECD, formal education, alternative education, and TEVT. The core 
document details the technical, managerial, regulatory, and financial issues, and the challenges 
involved in developing an integrated education system. The draft core document contains a well 
articulated and clear vision for SSR. It provides a solid basis for further elaboration of the reform 
process. 
 
31.  The core document acknowledges the achievements of EFA and the national movement 
that it has created. SSR is viewed as a combination of affirmative actions and policy changes 
aimed at attaining the EFA goals by 2015. At the same time, SSR builds upon lessons learned 
from EFA and attempts to address systemic issues that impede the progress of the education 
system. As such, the core document envisages a departure from the current program to a 
sector reform that is more responsive to the reality and needs of the school system. It envisages 
a school system that is needs-based, flexible, and autonomous. It intends to provide multiple 
educational choices to schools and communities with regard to learning content, medium of 
instruction, learning materials, and delivery methods. It envisages a contractual model between 
central  and  local  government  bodies  and  the  schools,  wherein  government  bodies  will  be 
responsible for providing minimum enabling conditions for learning, in exchange for which 
schools will be responsible for achieving an agreed standard for service delivery, learning 
achievements, and outcomes. The backbone of such a system is (i) a clear set of norms and 
standards; and (ii) an accountability mechanism that will define the roles, obligations, functions, 
and level of responsibilities at each institutional level.  
 
32.  Accountability is linked to quality improvement and assurance. Strategies to improve the 
quality and relevance of education have been strengthened. A prerequisite is the setting of 
norms and standards for quality improvement and assurance at all levels. Quality control is to 
be assured through the mechanism of an independent monitoring body accountable to the 
interministerial education policy committee (EPC). Quality is also to be measured by learning 
outcomes.  National  and  decentralized  public  school  examinations,  as  well  as  national 
assessment  of  learning  achievement  at  grades  5,  8,  and  10,  are  to  be  conducted,  and 
continuous student assessment will be introduced. The curriculum will be revised to make it 
more competency-based. Teachers’ minimum qualifications will be redefined according to the 
restructuring  of  grades  1–8  and  grades  9–12.  Guidelines  for  teacher  management  and 
development will be prepared. Strategies to improve the relevance of education to local needs 
include multigrade teaching and the development and teaching of local content curriculum.  
 
33.  In accordance with the interim constitution, the core document guarantees free basic 
education  to  all  children  and  encourages  local  governments  to  make  basic  education 
compulsory. Responsibilities for assuring equity of access and social inclusion will be shared 
between levels of government. A range of affirmative actions to support education for girls and 
disadvantaged groups has been defined. The core document proposes multiple options for

9 
 
school financing, including block grants, performance-based grants, and formula-based school 
grants.       
 
B.  The Core Document Challenges 
 
34.  The core document preparation comes after (i) a thorough process of thematic group 
works; (ii) a series of central, regional, district, and community-level stakeholder consultations; 
and (iii) periodic review and endorsement of the process by the EPC. Stakeholder consultation 
entails a lengthy process of consensus building among stakeholders with differing backgrounds 
and interests. Therefore the core document at this stage accommodates the views of various 
stakeholders and suggests multiple options for strategies and operational procedures. With the 
political uncertainties, the core document also remains cautious in some policy areas which may 
be directly influenced by future political and governance structures. As a result, further decisions 
are required and inconsistencies need to be resolved in the draft core document. However, the 
Government  vision  and  long-term  goal  for  SSR  is  clear  and  firm.  Consensus  among 
stakeholders  around  basic  principles  of  the  reform  is  strong.  The  challenge  is  to  build 
consensus and deepen analysis on how to achieve SSR goals in a realistic and sustainable 
manner. The major tasks and challenges will be (i) prioritization of the many areas of suggested 
policy reforms; (ii) adjustment and streamlining of the multiple strategic options; and (iii) policy 
decisions on phased and focused reform planning and process, including securing adequate 
financial resources. 
 
35.  Some policy directions will be subject to the outcomes of the political process, the 
ensuing revised government structure, and the degree of decentralization. These policies are 
(i) education  governance,  including  the  roles  and  mandates  of  local  government  bodies, 
communities,  and  schools;  (ii)  the  envisaged  cost-sharing  responsibilities  in  secondary 
education versus the policy of free secondary education as stated in the interim constitution; 
(iii) the roles and mandates of private education; and (iv) budget scenarios for the expansion to 
a grade 1–8 system and eventually an integrated grade 1–12 school system. Other key areas in 
the core document can be further analyzed and detailed without the need for the political 
process to be finalized. These include (i) finding an appropriate balance between the goals of 
improving access to, and quality of, education; (ii) establishing suitable incentive, accountability, 
and performance monitoring systems at all levels (central, district, and SMC); (iii) determining 
the most appropriate forms of affirmative action to enhance social inclusion; and (iv) determining 
an appropriate rationale and strategy for TEVT through formal and nonformal means, including 
the possibility of adding a vocational stream in school education. These issues are described 
below. 
 
36.  Improving Education Quality. The core document rightfully stresses the importance of 
improving the quality of education by modernizing pedagogy, curriculum, teacher skills, learning 
materials, assessment, and professional development of teachers and head teachers. Further 
analysis  will  need  to  clarify  the  envisaged  balance  between  quantitative  inputs,  such  as 
additional classrooms and teachers needed for grade 1–8 basic education, and inputs which are 
more  directly  related  to  quality  improvement.  Increased  public  demand  for  education  will 
continue pressuring the Government to expand access to grade 1–8 basic education. At the 
same time, there will be higher expectations for quality and performance of public schools. SSR 
will need to ensure that achieving quantitative access targets will not undermine quality targets. 
 
37.  Incentives  and  Accountability.  International  and  regional  experience  shows  that 
providing more teachers, classrooms, and textbooks does not necessarily lead to better-quality

10 
 
education. While additional inputs are necessary, they are not all that is needed to improve 
quality. The key ingredient stimulating quality is an appropriate system of accountability and 
incentives that motivates students, teachers, and schools to perform well. The core document 
proposes to improve educational quality by establishing a common threshold and minimum 
enabling  conditions,  linked  to  quantitative  inputs,  as  a  guide  for  raising  school  standards. 
Simultaneously, incentives for students and teachers are proposed. Further details on how the 
proposed incentives are expected to contribute to improving the quality of education are to be 
developed.  For  instance,  the  correlation  between  the  incentives  given  to  teachers,  head 
teachers, and SMCs, and the expected increase in the level of school performance, needs to be 
clarified.     
 
38.  More accountability will lead to better quality only if the districts and SMCs are provided 
with adequate resources and incentives for the stakeholders to fulfill their obligations, e.g., 
through  the  implementation  of  SIPs.  Furthermore,  apart  from  providing  positive  incentives, 
school and educational performance must be monitored more carefully in order to detect and 
act upon unsatisfactory fulfillment of obligations. 
 
39.  Social Inclusion. Social inclusion remains a key policy reform area. The core document 
emphasizes the need to improve the access to education by girls and disadvantaged groups 
such as dalit, madhesis,7 and mountain communities. Advanced policy and strategy options and 
a range of actions, including inclusive education and affirmative actions, have been included. 
The core document would benefit from further analysis of the implementation progress of, and 
lessons learned from, the current EFA program in these areas. Policies designed to enhance 
social inclusion should be consistent with those designed to raise the quality of education. For 
instance,  affirmative  actions  for  the  recruitment  of  female  teachers  and  those  from 
disadvantaged groups are to be carefully planned without compromising defined standards for 
teacher qualification.   
 
40.  Technical  Education  and  Vocational  Training.  Regional  experience  shows  that 
positive arguments and positive rates of return for spending on formal TEVT can be found in 
strong economies. In weaker economies, nonformal skills centers can have a much higher rate 
of return than formal vocational streams in secondary education. The feasibility of continuing 
costly investments in formal TEVT should be carefully considered in order to minimize risks that 
such investments will undermine investments in general education. Cost-sharing is necessary. 
The core document proposes continuation of the current centrally driven TEVT programs, and 
the addition of vocational streams in secondary education from grade 9 onwards. The proposed 
delegation of authority of TEVT to local levels and cost sharing, including the feasibility of 
public-private  partnership,  will  need  careful  consideration.  A  strong  economic  argument  is 
needed for continuing with formal TEVT and adding the vocational stream in school education.

disadvantaged groups. The expected outcome of ESP subprogram II is a broadly accepted and

48.  The expected outputs of the ESP subprogram II are (i) a revised SSR core document,

sector  reform.  It  is  expected  that  lessons  learned  and  experiences  gained  from  the

enable  them  to  act  as  self-governing  independent  entities,  and  individual  schools  will  be 
provided  with  technical  support  to  develop  capacity  for  self-management  and  governance. 
Critical  areas  of  capacity  development  envisaged  at  the  school  level  include  (i)  teacher

15 
 
mobilization; (ii) teacher, curriculum, and leadership development; (iii) resource mobilization; (iv) 
reporting  and  communication  with  parents;  (v)  instructional  planning;  (vi)  collaboration  and 
networking; (vii) action research; and (viii) social auditing. Major focus for capacity-development 
activities will be given to low-performing schools and those in disadvantaged areas.  
 
C.  Financing Plan  
  
61.  Costs of the early implementation of the SSR in the three model-building districts, as well 
as overall capacity development, are estimated at approximately $16 million. These include (i) 
costs associated with the development of new learning materials, (ii) additional teacher salaries 
and training, (iii) improvement of the school environment, (iv) enhancement of quality and social 
inclusion,  (v)  additional  SIP  grants  and  scholarships,  (vi)  capacity-development  activities  for 
overall system preparedness, and (vii) monitoring of management and administrative costs. The 
recurrent costs for operating the school system during the transition phase, which include regular 
teacher salaries in the concerned districts and salary of staff at the central and district level 
involved in the SSR transitional plan, have not been incorporated into this cost estimate as they 
will be borne by the Government. 
 
62.  The Government has requested a program grant of $8 million from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources to contribute to the SSR transitional plan. In parallel with the ADB grant, as part of the 
European Commission contribution to the school sector, the European Commission will provide a 
program grant of €6 million to support organizational capacity-development activities, both within 
key sector institutions in the country and with major stakeholders and communities. All EFA 
development partners have agreed to jointly finance the Program within the existing EFA JFA.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
63.  Program Management. MOES is the Executing Agency and DOE is the Implementing 
Agency. A central-level coordination committee has been established at MOES to effectively 
coordinate and monitor SSR capacity-development activities implemented by various MOES line 
agencies,  and  report  to  EPC  on  SSR  policy  implementation  initiatives.  The  central-level 
coordination committee is chaired by the joint secretary of the MOES Planning Division and 
comprises  representatives  from  MOES,  DOE,  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  the  National 
Planning Commission and other education line agencies. Similarly, a regional implementation 
team in each region and a district implementation team in the three model-building districts will be 
established. The technical secretariat at MOES will provide technical support to model-building 
districts. The interministerial EPC, chaired by the Minister of Education and Sports, will approve 
SSR policy options and the core document based on the inputs provided by the central-level 
coordination committee.  
 
64.  Implementation Period. The ESP subprogram II will be implemented over 4 years from 
January 2008 to December 2011. It is expected that program completion will be in December 
2011 and the grant closing date will be June 2012. 
 
65.  Tranching and Monitoring. The grant will be released in a single tranche. The tranche 
will be released to the foreign exchange account (FEA) held by MOES at the Nepal Rastra Bank, 
and established under the EFA’s JFA upon fulfilling all tranche release conditions. Funds will be 
released from the FEA to the government consolidated fund based on submission of actual 
expenditures by MOES and approval by MOF.

16 
 
66.  The SSR transitional plan and its detailed activities under ESP subprogram II will be jointly 
appraised by the Government and all development partners. This transitional plan will incorporate 
(i) activities of model-building districts transforming into a grade 1–8 basic education system, and 
(ii) activities for capacity development for the school sector as a whole. Activities with costs, which 
address both immediate priorities as well as preparing for longer-term reforms, will be provided for 
each year. Concrete and measurable indicators will be included. Monitoring of progress on the 
transitional plan will be integrated into the ongoing ASIP and AWPB. 
 
67.  Disbursement, Procurement, and Recruitment. The proceeds of the grant will be 
disbursed to MOF as the recipient in accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of 
Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans.10 The grant proceeds 
will be used to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items 
produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding ineligible items (Appendix 4) and 
imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. No supporting import documentation 
will be required if, during each year that grant proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value 
of  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and  imports 
financed under other official development assistance, is equal to or greater than the amount of 
the grant expected to be disbursed during such year. The Government will certify its compliance 
with this formula with its withdrawal request. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of grant 
proceeds and verify the accuracy of the Government’s certification. Procurement of eligible 
items and recruitment of consultants will be on the basis of standard Government procurement 
and  recruitment  practices  acceptable  to  ADB  for  procurement  and  recruitment  by  the 
Government or its representatives. 
 
68.  Counterpart Funds. The local currency funds generated from the proceeds of the 
program  grant  will  be  used  by  the  Government  to  supplement  the  cost  associated  with 
implementation of the SSR transitional plan. 
 
69.  Fund Flow Mechanism. The EFA’s JFA will be amended to incorporate SSR transitional 
activities under ESP subprogram II. The amended JFA will provide details of (i) the responsibilities 
of  the  Government  of  Nepal  and  of  participating  development  partners;  (ii)  the  funding 
mechanism;  (iii)  fiduciary  requirements,  including  procurement,  reporting,  monitoring,  and 
auditing; and (iv) other administrative requirements. An additional budget head account to the 
existing 10 EFA budget head accounts will be opened within the EFA JFA to channel funds for the 
SSR transitional activities. Reporting and monitoring of progress on SSR transitional activities will 
be  fully  integrated  into  the  ongoing  ASIP  and  AWPB.  MOES  will  provide  an  annual  draft 
procurement plan to the development partners for their review, and procurement monitoring 
reports will be provided in each trimester during program period. Procurement of works, goods, 
and services for the Program will follow procedures and regulations specified in the Government’s 
Procurement Act 2007 and the Procurement Regulations 2007.  
 
70.  The responsibility for implementing the program will rest with MOES and DOE. MOES will 
use the Government’s reporting system to submit the FMR to the pooled development partners 
each trimester. Replenishment of the funds from the FEA will be based on the timely and accurate 
submission of the FMR. The ESP subprogram II will be audited by the Office of the Auditor 
General of Nepal in accordance with auditing standards. The audited statements will be provided 
to the partners within 6 months of the end of each fiscal year.  
 
                                                 
10 ADB. 1998. Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. Manila.

17 
 
71.  Program  funds  will  be  made  available  in  two  steps.  Firstly,  grant  proceeds  will  be 
deposited in the FEA held by MOES in accordance with the respective provisions of grant 
agreements between the Government and the respective pooled development partners. While the 
funds will be pooled, each pooling partners’ accounts will be recorded, reconciled, and reflected 
separately in the FMR. Under Government procedures, no direct payments can be made from the 
FEA. Secondly, funds will be transferred from the FEA to the Government’s consolidated fund 
based on submission of actual expenditures by MOES and approval by MOF. However, MOES 
will transfer the funds from the FEA to the Government’s consolidated fund only upon receipt of 
the approval of FMR from the pooled development partners.  
 
E.  Program Risks  
 
72.  Nepal’s ongoing political transition may delay some aspects of the reform process. 
Strategies related to some areas of education governance, financing, and structure may be 
decided at a later stage. However, the model-building exercise, capacity-development activities 
and further preparation in key education reform areas of quality improvement and assurance, 
and social inclusion, do not require the political transition to be finalized, and hence will not be 
affected. Anticorruption measures under ESP subprogram II will follow the provisions under the 
EFA’s JFA. In particular, EFA partners endorsed a financial management improvement action 
plan prepared by DOE. The EFA midterm review concluded that the budgeting, accounting, and 
reporting  procedures  under  the  JFA  comply  with  fiduciary  requirements  in  an  acceptable 
manner. DOE is undertaking measures to (i) improve financial management pertinent to timely 
disbursement  to  districts  and  schools  and  submission  of  the  FMR,  (ii)  simplify  and  clarify 
guidelines, and (iii) strengthen monitoring and coordination mechanisms at all levels. DOE’s 
action plan for financial management improvement also comprises capacity development in 
social auditing and school auditing. Both ESP subprograms I and II have provisions to support 
such capacity development.    
  
F.  Compliance with Social Safeguard Policies 
    
73.  ESP subprogram II will have a positive impact on the socially disadvantaged groups, as 
social  inclusion  is  a  key  theme  of  the  draft  core  document.  The  vulnerable  communities 
development framework developed under ESP subprogram I will remain relevant under ESP 
subprogram II. Civil works will consist of additional classrooms to accommodate grades 6–8 in 
basic education schools in the model-building districts. Approximately 200 classrooms will be 
constructed.  The  Government  has  undertaken  an  initial  survey  of  land  requirements  to 
implement the model-building exercise and has concluded that no land acquisition will take 
place under the Program. No significant adverse environmental impacts are anticipated in this 
Program.  
 
VII.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
 
74.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government has given the following specific 
assurances, which are incorporated in the draft Grant Agreement: 
(i)  MOES and DOE will implement, manage, coordinate and monitor the Program in 
accordance  with  its  goals,  responsibilities,  funding  mechanism,  fiduciary 
requirements, and other program management arrangements as set out in the 
draft SSR core document and agreed in the EFA JFA;

18 
 
(ii)  MOES will implement and manage the Program in accordance with the vulnerable 
communities development framework agreed upon between MOES and ADB;  
(iii)  No activities under the Program will entail land acquisition or other resettlement 
activities under ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995);  
(iv)  Throughout the program period, the budget share for education will remain at least 
at the level of FY2008, while all efforts will be made to increase the budget 
allocation; and  
(v)  MOES will ensure compliance with existing environmental laws and regulations of 
Nepal, as well as ADB’s Environment Policy (2002).  
 
B.  Conditions for Grant Effectiveness  
 
75.  The following are conditions for grant effectiveness:  
(i)  the Government will have issued an executive order enabling MOES to restructure, 
on a pilot basis, 1–8 basic education in Rasuwa District, Dadeldhura District, and 
Kapilvastu District;    
(ii)  all policy actions set forth in the policy matrix will have been complied with; and  
(iii)  the amendments to the EFA JFA, required to use such EFA JFA for financing any 
SSR-related activities, shall have become effective.    
 
VIII.  RECOMMENDATION 
76.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $8,000,000 to Nepal from the ADB’s Special Funds resources for 
the  Education  Sector  Program  Cluster  (Subprogram  II),  on  terms  and  conditions  that  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft Grant Agreement presented to the 
Board.
